TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi sealed beforefieldinit VBuffer`1<T> extends System.ValueType

Docs.typeparam: The type of the vector. There are no compile-time restrictions on what this could be, but this code and practically all code that uses makes the assumption that an assignment of a value is sufficient to make a completely independent copy of it. So, for example, this means that a buffer of buffers is not possible. But, things like , , and , are totally fine.
Docs.summary: A buffer that supports both dense and sparse representations. This is the representation type for all instances. The explicitly defined values of this vector are exposed through and, if not dense, .
Docs.remarks:
This structure is by itself immutable, but to enable buffer editing including re-use of the internal buffers, a mutable variant can be accessed through .
Throughout the code, we make the assumption that a sparse is logically equivalent to a dense with the default value for filling in the default values.

Public Sub New (length As Integer, values As T(), Optional indices As Integer() = null)
new Microsoft.ML.Data.VBuffer<'T> : int * 'T[] * int[] -> Microsoft.ML.Data.VBuffer<'T>

Docs.param: The logical length of the resulting instance.
The values to be used. This must be at least as long as . If is 0, it is legal for this to be . The constructed buffer takes ownership of this array.

The internal indices buffer. Because this constructor is for dense representations this will not be immediately useful, but it does provide a buffer to be potentially reused to avoid allocation. This is mostly non-null in situations where you want to produce a dense , but you happen to have an indices array "left over" and you don't want to needlessly lose.
Docs.summary: Construct a dense representation. The array is often unspecified, but if specified it should be considered a buffer to be held on to, to be possibly used.
Docs.remarks: The resulting structure takes ownership of the passed in arrays, so they should not be used for other purposes in the future.

Docs.param: The length of the constructed buffer.
The count of explicit entries. This must be between 0 and , both inclusive. If it equals the result is a dense vector, and if less this will be a sparse vector.
The values to be used. This must be at least as long as . If is 0, it is legal for this to be .
The indices to be used. If we are constructing a dense representation, or is 0, this can be . Otherwise, this must be at least as long as .
Docs.summary: Construct a possibly sparse vector representation.
Docs.remarks: The resulting structure takes ownership of the passed in arrays, so they should not be used for other purposes in the future.

MemberSignature.Value: public ReadOnlySpan<int> GetIndices ();
.method public hidebysig instance valuetype System.ReadOnlySpan`1<int32> GetIndices() cil managed
Public Function GetIndices () As ReadOnlySpan(Of Integer)
member this.GetIndices : unit -> ReadOnlySpan<int>

Docs.summary: The indices. For a dense representation, this array is not used, and will return the default "empty" span. For a sparse representation it is parallel to that returned from and specifies the logical indices for the corresponding values, in increasing order, between 0 inclusive and exclusive, corresponding to all explicitly defined values. All values at unspecified indices should be treated as being implicitly defined with the default value of .
Docs.remarks: To give one example, if returns [3, 5] and () produces [98, 76], this stands for a vector with non-zero values 98 and 76 respectively at the 4th and 6th coordinates, and zeros at all other indices. (Zero, because that is the default value for all .NET numeric types.)

Docs.param: The index, which must be a non-negative number less than .

Docs.returns: The value stored at that index, or if this is a sparse vector where this is an implicit entry, the default value for .

MemberSignature.Value: public void GetItemOrDefault (int index, ref T destination);
.method public hidebysig instance void GetItemOrDefault(int32 index, !T& destination) cil managed
Public Sub GetItemOrDefault (index As Integer, ByRef destination As T)
member this.GetItemOrDefault : int * -> unit

Docs.param: The index, which must be a non-negative number less than .
The value stored at that index, or if this is a sparse vector where this is an implicit entry, the default value for .
Docs.summary: Gets the item stored in this structure. In the case of a dense vector this is a simple lookup. In the case of a sparse vector, it will try to find the entry with that index, and set to that stored value, or if no such value was found, assign it the default value.
Docs.remarks:
In the case where is , this will take constant time since it an directly lookup. For sparse vectors, however, because it must perform a bisection search on the indices to find the appropriate value, that takes logarithmic time with respect to the number of explicitly represented items, which is to say, the of the return value of .
For that reason, a single completely isolated lookup, since constructing as does is not a free operation, it may be more efficient to use this method. However if one is doing a more involved computation involving many operations, it may be faster to utiltize and, if appropriate, directly.

MemberSignature.Value: public readonly int Length;
.field public initonly int32 Length
Public ReadOnly Length As Integer
val mutable Length : int

Docs.summary: The logical length of the buffer.
Docs.remarks: Note that if this vector , then this will be the same as the as returned from , since all values are explicitly represented in a dense representation. If this is a sparse representation, then that will be somewhat shorter, as this field contains the number of both explicit and implicit entries.
